skill.name: vaex
skill.description: Use this skill for processing and analyzing large tabular datasets (billions of rows) that exceed available RAM. Vaex excels at out-of-core DataFrame operations, lazy evaluation, fast aggregations, efficient visualization of big data, and machine learning on large datasets. Apply when users need to work with large CSV/HDF5/Arrow/Parquet files, perform fast statistics on massive datasets, create visualizations of big data, or build ML pipelines that don't fit in memory.
skill.summary: Use this skill for processing and analyzing large tabular datasets (billions of rows) that exceed av...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only reference guides and Python code examples for the Vaex library. All 501 static findings are false positives triggered by documentation patterns. The analyzer misinterprets markdown code examples, placeholder credential documentation, and legitimate feature descriptions as security issues. No executable code, network operations, or credential exposure exists.

content.value_statement: Working with large datasets that exceed RAM causes memory errors and slow performance. Vaex uses lazy evaluation and memory-mapping to process billions of rows instantly without loading data into memory.
actual_capabilities: Load and process datasets larger than available RAM using memory-mapping
Perform fast statistical aggregations on billion-row datasets
Create virtual columns without memory overhead
Build machine learning pipelines with sklearn, XGBoost, and LightGBM integration
Visualize large datasets with heatmaps and histograms
limitations: Not a drop-in replacement for pandas in all scenarios
Requires converting data to HDF5 or Arrow format for optimal performance
Some pandas operations not available in Vaex
May require code changes when migrating from pandas

use_cases.title: Analyze massive datasets
use_cases.description: Explore and analyze datasets with billions of rows without memory errors or sampling.

use_cases.title: Train models on big data
use_cases.description: Build and deploy ML pipelines on datasets too large for traditional tools.

use_cases.title: Process time-series data
use_cases.description: Work with large financial time-series data for risk analysis and forecasting.

prompt_templates.title: Load large dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Load a large HDF5/Parquet file with Vaex and show basic statistics and column info.

prompt_templates.title: Filter and aggregate
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter the dataset by condition and compute groupby aggregations efficiently.

prompt_templates.title: Create visualizations
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a heatmap or histogram visualization of the large dataset.

prompt_templates.title: Build ML pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Preprocess features using Vaex ML transformers and train an XGBoost model.

output_examples.input: Load my 10GB sales data file and show the distribution of revenue by region
Create a virtual column for BMI from height and weight columns
Show the top 10 customers by total purchase amount

best_practices: Convert CSV files to HDF5 or Arrow format for instant loading
Use virtual columns instead of materializing data to save memory
Batch multiple operations with delay=True for single-pass computation
Leverage selections instead of creating new DataFrames for filtering
anti_patterns: Using .to_pandas_df() on large datasets defeats Vaex's purpose
Converting data to NumPy arrays with .values when not needed
Exporting to CSV repeatedly instead of using HDF5/Arrow
Materializing virtual columns without good reason

faq.question: How does Vaex handle datasets larger than RAM?
faq.answer: Vaex memory-maps files, keeping data on disk and reading only accessed portions into memory.

faq.question: What file formats work best with Vaex?
faq.answer: HDF5 and Apache Arrow provide instant loading. CSV is slow for large files.

faq.question: Can I use Vaex with pandas code?
faq.answer: Vaex has similar API to pandas but some operations differ. Full pandas compatibility is not guaranteed.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using Vaex?
faq.answer: Vaex never modifies source files. All transformations create virtual columns or new exports.

faq.question: Why are my operations running slowly?
faq.answer: Check that you are using HDF5/Arrow format, not CSV. Use delay=True for multiple aggregations.

faq.question: How does Vaex compare to Dask or Polars?
faq.answer: Vaex excels at billion-row datasets with minimal memory. Dask handles distributed computing, Polars is faster for in-memory data.
